title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: While the expression of some genes remained steady, for example, Jam2 in arteriolar endothelial cells and Ihh in chondrocytes, the expression of Vcam1, Pcdh7 and Il7 was lost in the TME, especially at the end point. Expression of Anxa1 first increased but then declined towards the end. The fourth category of genes was always expressed, but the microenvironmental populations expressing them changed. These included Pvr, Cdo1, Apoe and Agt (Extended Data Fig. 3a–d)
outcome: Our analysis capturing dynamic changes in the TME identifies signals that may be necessary not only at different stages of disease progression, but also those critical during the entire course of disease

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

context: SLC6A6 encodes TAUT, which has high affinity for the non-essential amino acid taurine, and low affinity for β-alanine (taurine Km = 4.5 μM versus β-alanine Km = 56 μM)22

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: While the leukaemia TME did not express enzymes required for β-alanine synthesis (Gadl1 and Cndp1), those needed for taurine biosynthesis were expressed in osteo-associated cells (Cdo1 and Csad; Extended Data Fig. 4h,i)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our analysis of the limited numbers of stromal cells in these samples indicate that CDO1 expression is restricted to the MSC/osteolineage cells (Extended Data Fig. 4k,l)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: we found a marked increase in CDO1 protein expression in nearly all matched biopsies of patients who progressed from MDS to secondary AML, and those who relapsed after AML diagnosis (Fig. 2d–g and Extended Data Fig. 4m–p)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: While CDO1 protein was expressed in undifferentiated human AML MSCs, its expression increased during in vitro mouse and human AML MSC osteogenic differentiation (Extended Data Fig. 5a–c)
outcome: Thus, CDO1 may be broadly expressed in immature MSCs as well as differentiating osteolineage cells in human bone marrow

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Importantly, taurine levels in extracellular medium increased during MSC differentiation

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: To determine a functional role of taurine from osteolineage cells
outcome: we tested the impact of inhibiting taurine biosynthesis in mouse and human leukaemia bone-marrow-derived MSCs on co-cultured leukaemia cells

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our experiments showed that mouse LSCs co-cultured with osteolineage cells lacking Cdo1 expression were significantly less viable (about 2-fold lower than the controls) and formed fewer colonies (3.4-fold less than controls), which could be rescued by supplementing cultures with taurine (Extended Data Fig. 5e–g)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: inhibiting CDO1 in osteolineage cultures from MSCs derived from patients with AML impaired survival and colony-formation of co-cultured AML cells from the same patient by 2- to 3.2-fold (Fig. 2h,i and Extended Data Fig. 5h)
outcome: indicating that taurine produced by osteolineage cells promotes LSC growth and survival

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: taurine levels were 1.7-fold higher in leukaemic bone marrow interstitial fluid as compared to the controls (Fig. 2j)
context: Consistent with a functional role of taurine from the TME in leukaemia progression

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

context: In mice, the majority of taurine is synthesized in the liver from cysteine24
outcome: we generated a new Cdo1fl/fl mouse model and crossed it to MSC/osteolineage-specific Prrx1-cre mice (Extended Data Fig. 5i–k)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: We did not find any significant changes in the composition of TME in Cdo1fl/flPrrx1-cre+ leukaemic mice as compared to the controls (Extended Data Fig. 5l–n)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: We finally tested whether exogenous taurine supplements can promote leukaemia growth

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our experiments showed that the colony-forming ability of mouse LSCs and patient-derived AML cells increased by 1.2- to 3.3-fold in the presence of taurine (Extended Data Fig. 5o–q)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Taurine supplements could significantly accelerate disease progression in immunocompetent mice (around threefold higher likelihood of death relative to the controls; Extended Data Fig. 5r)
outcome: indicating that taurine can promote leukaemic progression

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: To determine whether TAUT has a functional role in leukaemia progression

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our experiments showed that TAUT loss in LSCs significantly reduced their ability to grow when co-cultured with osteolineage cells expressing either control shRNA or shRNA against Cdo1 (shCdo1; Extended Data Fig. 6a)
outcome: indicating that they could not respond to taurine being produced by the niche

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: TAUT loss impaired initiation of bcCML in mouse models (3.9-fold higher likelihood of survival; Fig. 3c,d), which could not be rescued with taurine supplements (Extended Data Fig. 6b)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: TAUT loss also led to functional depletion in bcCML LSCs, as indicated by a 2.3-fold reduction in their colony-forming ability (Fig. 3e), as well as a marked increase in the survival of mice transplanted with Slc6a6−/− LSCs (40%) relative to control LSCs (0%) in secondary transplant assays (21.2-fold higher likelihood of survival; Fig. 3f)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: The 8.5-fold reduction in colony-forming ability of bcCML LSCs from secondary transplants (Fig. 3g,h)
outcome: suggests that these leukaemias remain dependent on TAUT expression and taurine uptake for their continued propagation

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: We noted no significant differences in bone marrow microenvironmental populations of mice bearing Slc6a6−/− leukaemias as compared to the controls
outcome: indicating that leukaemia-driven niche remodelling possibly reflects the extent of the tumour burden, and may be independent of taurine levels within leukaemia cells (Extended Data Fig. 6c–g)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: To determine whether TAUT is broadly required for de novo AML growth
outcome: we tested the impact of its loss on initiation of leukaemia driven by MLL-AF9/NRAS(G12V) and by AML-ETO9a/NRAS(G12V)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our experiments showed that TAUT loss markedly delays the initiation of MLL-driven AML relative to the control (6.1-fold higher likelihood of survival; Fig. 3i–k)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Slc6a6−/− KIT+ AML LSCs from established disease formed 2.9-fold fewer colonies compared with the controls (Fig. 3l)
outcome: indicating that TAUT loss depleted functional LSCs

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: TAUT loss in disease driven by AML-ETO9a resulted in a marked increase in survival (70%) relative to the controls (0%) (36.3-fold higher likelihood of survival; Fig. 3m,n)
context: Consistent with a key role of TAUT expression in myeloid leukaemia initiation

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: At the cellular level, TAUT loss led to a 2.4- to 3.6-fold reduction in primitive Lin− CD150− FLT3+ SCA1+ LSCs6 (Fig. 3o)

main_content: Furthermore, TAUT loss increased necrosis and the Lin+ differentiated cells (Fig. 3p and Extended Data Fig. 6h) and promoted cell proliferation (Fig. 3q)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our analysis indicates that TAUT loss does not severely impact bone marrow cellularity, or the total numbers of HSCs, progenitors and differentiated cells at steady-state (Extended Data Fig. 7a–e)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: While TAUT loss did not impair initial HSC engraftment (1 month after transplant), donor chimerism dropped over time (Extended Data Fig. 7f,g)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Although overall bone marrow chimerism 4 months after transplant was 2.4-fold lower in Slc6a6−/− HSC recipients as compared to Slc6a6+/+ HSC recipients, these Slc6a6−/− HSCs were able to contribute to all haematopoietic lineages (Extended Data Fig. 7h–k)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Serial transplantation of Slc6a6+/+ and Slc6a6−/− bone marrow cells showed a similar loss in Slc6a6−/− engraftment over time (Extended Data Fig. 7l–q)
outcome: These results suggest that, while TAUT loss does not impair steady-state haematopoiesis, it can impact long-term HSC self-renewal and maintenance

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: These data

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

main_content: We find increased SLC6A6 expression in leukaemia cells carrying RAS mutations as compared to wild-type cells (Fig. 4c)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
subsection: TAUT is essential for human AML growth
main_content: To determine whether small-molecule inhibitors of TAUT can effectively block leukaemia growth
outcome: we used two well-characterized structural analogues of taurine that inhibit uptake: 6-aminomethyl-3-methyl-4H-1,2,4-benzothiadiazine-1,1-dioxide hydrochloride35 (TAG) and guanidinoethyl sulphonate36 (GES; Extended Data Fig. 8d,e)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

main_content: TAG and GES treatment led to a substantial reduction in colonies formed by Slc6a6+/+ mouse LSCs but not Slc6a6−/− cells (Extended Data Fig. 8f–h)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
subsection: TAUT is essential for human AML growth
main_content: while TAG and GES impaired growth of primary human AML cells in colony assays by 1.8- to 20-fold, they did not impact normal human CD34+ HSPC colony growth (Fig. 4d,e)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
subsection: TAUT is essential for human AML growth
main_content: Our experiments showed that venetoclax reduced the viability of mouse Slc6a6−/− LSCs by 3.2-fold and lowered their colony formation by 13.2-fold as compared to the controls (Extended Data Fig. 8i,j)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
subsection: TAUT is essential for human AML growth
main_content: While TAG, GES or venetoclax alone could impair mouse LSC colony formation by 1.4- to 3.9-fold, their combination was synergistic and led to 2.3- to 7.2-fold fewer colonies as compared to the controls (Extended Data Fig. 8k–m)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
subsection: TAUT is essential for human AML growth
main_content: While primary human AML cells that were treated with GES, TAG or venetoclax alone formed 1.3- to 8.3-fold fewer colonies as compared to the controls, combining the treatments substantially impaired colony formation by 2.4- to 150-fold
outcome: These data indicate that taurine inhibitors can synergize with venetoclax in blocking the growth of human AML cells (Fig. 4f–h)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis

main_content: while SLC6A6 knockdown reduced the engraftment of primary AML cells by 1.2- to 40-fold in patient-derived xenograft models (Fig. 4k,l), it did not significantly impair engraftment of normal human CD34+ HSPCs in xenograft models (Fig. 4m)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: To establish the mechanisms by which taurine uptake in leukaemia cells promotes disease progression
outcome: we determined metabolic changes in the absence of taurine

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our untargeted metabolomic analysis of mouse LSCs identified significant downregulation of glycolysis/TCA related pathways and metabolites such as pyruvate, glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate and 3-phosphoglycerate in Slc6a6−/− cells
outcome: suggesting that taurine may regulate energy metabolism (Fig. 5a–c and Extended Data Fig. 10a)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: we noted a 1.3- to 1.8-fold reduction in basal glycolysis, glycolytic capacity, maximal oxygen consumption and spare respiratory capacity in Slc6a6−/− LSCs as compared to the controls (Fig. 5d,e and Extended Data Fig. 10b)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: To functionally test the role of glycolysis and TCA associated metabolites... [and] determine whether bypassing these could rescue Slc6a6−/− defects

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our experiments showed that the colony-forming ability of Slc6a6−/− LSCs could be significantly rescued by pyruvate, sodium acetate and lactate, but not glucagon (Fig. 5f and Extended Data Fig. 10c–e)
outcome: These data suggest that glycolysis, and not gluconeogenesis, is the primary downstream effector of taurine in leukaemia cells

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: tested whether taurine contributed to any cellular metabolite
outcome: by determining 13C-taurine incorporation in K562 leukaemia cells

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our untargeted metabolomic approach identified 13C label only in known taurine conjugates, N-acetyl taurine and glutaurine (Extended Data Fig. 10f,g)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Membrane-permeable taurine fully rescued colonies formed by Slc6a6−/− cells (Fig. 5g), and N-acetyl-taurine partly rescued this defect (Extended Data Fig. 10h)
context: perhaps by breakdown to taurine and acetate37

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: By contrast, glutaurine was unable to rescue the Slc6a6−/− colony formation (Extended Data Fig. 10i)
outcome: These experiments indicate that taurine, and not a secondary metabolite, promotes leukaemia growth due to an indirect effect on glycolysis, possibly through downstream signalling

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: To identify signals downstream of taurine
outcome: we performed RNA-seq as well as phosphoproteome and total-proteome analyses of primary mouse leukaemia cells (Fig. 5h)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our RNA-seq analysis identified 932 downregulated and 1,158 upregulated genes in the absence of TAUT (Padj < 0.05)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: The 1,158 upregulated genes included pathways associated with haematopoietic cell lineage and cell cycle regulation (Extended Data Fig. 11a,b)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: The 932 downregulated genes primarily constituted pathways associated with glycolysis (Fig. 5i and Extended Data Fig. 11b–d)
context: consistent with reduced abundance of glycolysis associated metabolites in these cells (Fig. 5c)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: To determine effectors of glycolytic downregulation on TAUT loss
outcome: we performed gene set enrichment analysis

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: This identified profound downregulation of oncogenic MYC and mTOR pathways (Fig. 5j and Extended Data Fig. 11c)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: tested whether TAUT loss impairs mTOR activation
context: As mTOR signalling is known to regulate expression of glycolysis related genes38

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Western blot analysis showed that TAUT loss results in a 2.2- to 3-fold reduction in activated mTOR, p70S6k and pEIF4B as compared to the controls (Fig. 5k–m and Extended Data Fig. 11e)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our global phosphoproteome and total-proteome analyses also showed reduced expression of phosphorylated proteins associated with mTOR signalling, as well as 3.3-fold reduced BCL2 and 1.5-fold increased LC3A expression in the absence of TAUT (Extended Data Fig. 11f,g)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Like TAUT loss, TAUT inhibition with TAG and GES downregulated glycolysis-related gene expression (Extended Data Fig. 11h,i) and impaired phosphorylation of mTOR signalling (Extended Data Fig. 12a,b)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: acute treatment in vitro and long-term taurine dosing in vivo could activate mTOR signalling (Extended Data Fig. 12c–h)
context: Consistent with a direct impact of taurine on mTOR signalling

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Inhibiting mTOR with rapamycin impaired the growth of wild-type cells but did not impact Slc6a6−/− cells in vitro or in vivo (Fig. 5n and Extended Data Fig. 12i,k)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: mTOR activation with MHY148539 rescued the colony-forming ability of Slc6a6−/− LSCs to 60% of the control, and membrane-permeable taurine rescued mTOR activation (Fig. 5o and Extended Data Fig. 12j–l)
outcome: Collectively, these data indicate that mTOR signalling has a key role downstream of taurine in leukaemia cells

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: We hypothesized that taurine may activate mTOR by promoting its interaction with RAG GTPases
context: Amino acid availability can be sensed by RAG GTPases to facilitate mTORC1 localization to the outer lysosomal membrane40 and its interaction with RHEB GTPases41, thereby promoting mTORC1 activation
outcome: To test this, we determined the effect of expressing constitutively active RAGA(Q66L) or RHEB(Q64L) on the colony-forming ability of Slc6a6 wild-type and null cells

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our experiments showed that, while RHEB(Q64L) partially rescued Slc6a6−/− colony formation, this could be fully rescued by RAGA(Q66L) (Fig. 5p)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Furthermore, mTOR phosphorylation in Slc6a6−/− cells could be rescued by RAGA(Q66L) (Extended Data Fig. 12m)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: directly tested whether taurine could promote mTOR interactions with lysosomes in wild-type and Slc6a6−/− leukaemia cells expressing RAGA(Q66L) (Fig. 5q)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Our immunofluorescence-based analysis showed that, at the baseline, Slc6a6−/− cells have 1.2-fold lower mTOR–LAMP1 interaction, which could be fully rescued by RAGA(Q66L)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: Taurine supplements increased mTOR–LAMP1 co-localization to levels seen in cells expressing RAGA(Q66L)

title: Taurine from tumour niche drives glycolysis to promote leukaemogenesis
main_content: However, this interaction could not be increased further by adding taurine to RAGA(Q66L)-expressing cells (Fig. 5r,s)
context: consistent with our colony-forming assays (Extended Data Fig. 12n)
outcome: Collectively, our studies show that the taurine–TAUT axis regulates glycolysis in myeloid leukaemia cells by promoting RAG-mediated activation of mTOR signalling
